epidemiology: Affects about 30% of adults globally; major risk factor for stroke, MI, heart failure, and CKD.
treatment_protocol: Assess risk → Lifestyle changes → Start monotherapy or dual therapy → Regular monitoring

epidemiology: Prevalence ~1–2% in general population; increases with age; major cause of hospitalization in elderly.
treatment_protocol: Confirm diagnosis → Classify HF type → Initiate GDMT → Monitor and titrate

epidemiology: Leading cause of death worldwide; highest incidence in men >45 and women >55 years.

emergency_markers: ST-elevation or new LBBB with chest pain

treatment_protocol: STEMI → Immediate PCI or thrombolysis → DAPT + statins → Cardiac rehab

epidemiology: Most common sustained arrhythmia; prevalence increases with age; associated with stroke risk.
treatment_protocol: Assess stability → Rate or rhythm control → Anticoagulate per CHADS2-VASc

epidemiology: Often idiopathic or viral; affects males more commonly; can be recurrent.

timeline.symptom: Sharp chest pain worsens with inspiration

emergency_markers: Tamponade signs: hypotension, muffled heart sounds, JVD

treatment_protocol: NSAIDs + Colchicine → Monitor → Drain if effusion → Address recurrence

epidemiology: Occurs in ~2% of population; more common in females; often benign but may cause complications.
treatment_protocol: Echo → Monitor severity → Surgery if symptomatic or regurgitation severe

epidemiology: Common in elderly; degenerative calcification most frequent cause; bicuspid aortic valve in younger patients.
treatment_protocol: Echo → Assess severity → Surgery/TAVR if symptomatic or LV dysfunction

epidemiology: Common arrhythmia, especially in young females; AVNRT most frequent form.
treatment_protocol: Assess stability → Vagal or adenosine → Prevent recurrence (ablation)

epidemiology: Rare but life-threatening; highest risk in IV drug users, prosthetic valves, and congenital heart defects.
treatment_protocol: Blood cultures → IV antibiotics → Echo → Surgery if indicated

epidemiology: Uncommon but fatal; incidence 2–3 per 100,000/year; more common in men aged 60–70.

timeline.symptom: Sudden tearing chest pain radiating to back
Pulse deficit or blood pressure difference

definitive: Medical for type B unless complicated

treatment_protocol: CT or TEE → Type A: surgery, Type B: control BP unless rupture

epidemiology: Prevalence ~1 in 2,500; leading cause of heart transplant; idiopathic in most cases.
treatment_protocol: Echo diagnosis → GDMT → ICD/CRT for EF <35% → Transplant if refractory

epidemiology: Less common than other cardiomyopathies; associated with infiltrative diseases like amyloidosis.
treatment_protocol: Differentiate from constrictive → Manage fluid → Address cause → Refer if refractory

epidemiology: Life-threatening arrhythmia; most common in patients with structural heart disease.
treatment_protocol: Assess stability → ACLS if needed → Antiarrhythmic → ICD/ablation for recurrence

epidemiology: Prevalence ~1 in 1,000; often presents in teens/young adults; associated with AVRT.
treatment_protocol: Diagnose via ECG → Ablation in symptomatic patients → Avoid AV nodal blockers

epidemiology: Rare genetic or acquired disorder; risk of torsades de pointes and sudden cardiac death.

emergency_markers: QTc > 500 ms with syncope or family history of sudden death

treatment_protocol: Identify cause → Correct contributors → Beta-blockers → ICD if high-risk

epidemiology: Prevalence is about 15–50 cases per million; higher in women and those with connective tissue diseases.
treatment_protocol: Echo → Right heart cath → Classify group → Initiate targeted therapy

epidemiology: Often viral; incidence ~10–22 per 100,000/year; affects young adults disproportionately.
treatment_protocol: Confirm by MRI → Supportive care → Monitor function → Immunotherapy selectively

epidemiology: Prevalent in patients with chronic lung disease; chronic hypoxia is major driver.
treatment_protocol: Diagnose underlying cause → Oxygen → RHF management

epidemiology: Affects ~1 in 600 elderly individuals; increasing prevalence with age and structural heart disease.
treatment_protocol: Symptomatic with bradycardia → Consider pacemaker

epidemiology: Congenital lesion; may persist or be acquired post-MI; small defects often asymptomatic.

emergency_markers: Acute VSD post-MI with hemodynamic collapse

treatment_protocol: Echo diagnosis → Monitor small VSD → Close if symptomatic or large

epidemiology: Persistent fetal circulation defect; more common in females and premature infants; often detected incidentally in adults.
treatment_protocol: Echo to confirm → Closure if significant shunt or symptomatic

epidemiology: Congenital narrowing of aorta; accounts for 5–8% of congenital heart defects; more common in males.
treatment_protocol: Confirm with imaging → Repair if gradient >20 mmHg or symptomatic

epidemiology: Often secondary to infection, malignancy, or post-surgical; can lead to tamponade.
treatment_protocol: Echo to assess size/effect → Drain if tamponade or symptomatic

epidemiology: Prevalence 1:500; autosomal dominant inheritance; most common cause of SCD in young athletes.
treatment_protocol: Echo + Risk stratification → Medical → Myectomy or ICD if indicated

epidemiology: Infiltrative cardiomyopathy; higher incidence in older adults, especially African descent; associated with AL or ATTR amyloidosis.
treatment_protocol: Suspect in thick LV + low volt ECG → Confirm subtype → Tailored therapy

epidemiology: Rare inherited arrhythmia syndrome; more common in Southeast Asian males; causes sudden cardiac death.

emergency_markers: ECG with Type I Brugada pattern and syncope or VF

treatment_protocol: Confirm Brugada pattern → ICD for syncope/VF → Screen family

epidemiology: Also called stress cardiomyopathy; predominantly affects postmenopausal women; triggered by emotional/physical stress.
treatment_protocol: Rule out MI → Echo pattern → Supportive therapy

epidemiology: Common cause of chest pain; idiopathic or viral most often; occurs post-MI (Dressler syndrome).
treatment_protocol: ECG + echo → NSAIDs + colchicine → Monitor effusion

epidemiology: Infective endocarditis affects ~3–10 per 100,000/year; IV drug users and valve disease patients are at risk.
treatment_protocol: Duke criteria → Blood cultures → Echo → Treat based on organism

epidemiology: Form of cardiac arrest with electrical activity but no pulse; common in trauma, hypoxia, acidosis.
treatment_protocol: Start CPR → Epinephrine → Address reversible causes (Hs and Ts)

epidemiology: Late complication of pericarditis or TB; common in developing countries; occurs after radiation, surgery.

emergency_markers: Signs of decompensated right heart failure

treatment_protocol: Confirm diagnosis via imaging → Surgical pericardiectomy

epidemiology: Most common congenital heart defect detected in adulthood; females affected more; secundum type is most prevalent.
treatment_protocol: Echo with bubble → Close if large or symptomatic

epidemiology: Congenital or drug-induced; prolongs ventricular repolarization; predisposes to torsades de pointes and SCD.

emergency_markers: QTc >500 ms with syncope or torsades

treatment_protocol: QTc >480 ms → Rule out secondary causes → Beta-blocker or ICD

epidemiology: Most common arrhythmia; increasing with age; common in HTN, CHF, and thyrotoxicosis.
treatment_protocol: Stable → Rate control → Stroke risk eval → Anticoagulation or rhythm strategy

epidemiology: Accessory pathway disorder; incidence 0.1–0.3%; may present as SVT or sudden cardiac death.

emergency_markers: AF with pre-excitation and wide QRS

supportive: Avoid AV nodal blockers in AF

treatment_protocol: Confirm delta wave → Ablation of accessory pathway

epidemiology: Common in elderly; may result from fibrosis, ischemia, or medications; also known as sick sinus syndrome.
treatment_protocol: Symptomatic bradycardia → Pacemaker implantation

epidemiology: Rare disorder; affects 15–50 per million; associated with connective tissue disease, chronic lung disease, or idiopathic.
treatment_protocol: Echo → RHC confirmation → Classify and treat accordingly

epidemiology: More common in men >60; associated with HTN, connective tissue disorders, or atherosclerosis.

definitive: Surgical repair if >5.5 cm or symptomatic

treatment_protocol: Monitor size → Surgical repair if indicated

epidemiology: Most common congenital heart defect in infancy; small defects may persist into adulthood asymptomatically.
treatment_protocol: Confirm size/shunt → Surgery if large/symptomatic

epidemiology: Rare granulomatous infiltration of myocardium; occurs in 5% of sarcoidosis patients; underdiagnosed cause of arrhythmia.
treatment_protocol: Suspected → MRI or PET → Biopsy or treat empirically

epidemiology: Life-threatening complication of pericardial effusion; may follow trauma, malignancy, or pericarditis.
treatment_protocol: Echo-confirmed effusion + instability → Pericardiocentesis

epidemiology: May be functional (due to RV dilation) or primary (endocarditis, trauma); common in pulmonary HTN and pacemaker leads.
treatment_protocol: Echo diagnosis → Treat cause → Consider surgery

epidemiology: Congenital in most cases; rare in adults; may present with symptoms only in severe cases.

emergency_markers: Severe obstruction with syncope or cyanosis

treatment_protocol: Echo-confirmed stenosis → Valvuloplasty if moderate/severe

epidemiology: Common in elderly; early form of calcific aortic stenosis; no obstruction of flow but associated with CV risk.
treatment_protocol: Routine echo monitoring; manage atherosclerosis

epidemiology: Rare congenital cardiomyopathy due to arrested endomyocardial development; can cause HF or arrhythmias.
treatment_protocol: Cardiac imaging → Risk stratification → Treat heart failure and prevent SCD

epidemiology: Congenital anomaly where coronary artery tunnels through myocardium; often benign, but may cause ischemia or arrhythmias.
treatment_protocol: Diagnose on imaging → Trial beta-blockers → Surgery if severe

epidemiology: Rare cause of restrictive cardiomyopathy due to eosinophilic infiltration; often related to hypereosinophilic syndrome.
treatment_protocol: Eosinophilia + cardiac symptoms → MRI or biopsy → Steroids +/- anticoagulation

epidemiology: Subtype of sick sinus syndrome; alternating bradycardia and tachyarrhythmias, especially in elderly.
treatment_protocol: Document pauses + AF → Pacemaker → Anticoagulation

epidemiology: Rare variant angina; occurs at rest and often during night; seen in smokers and cocaine users.
treatment_protocol: ST elevation + clean coronaries → CCB + nitrate

epidemiology: More common in prosthetic valves, IVDU, or valvular heart disease; caused by Staph, Strep, Enterococci.
treatment_protocol: 3x blood cultures → Empiric IV antibiotics → Tailor to sensitivity

epidemiology: Stress-induced cardiomyopathy, more common in postmenopausal women; often triggered by emotional or physical stress.

definitive: Supportive care, resolves spontaneously in most cases

treatment_protocol: Exclude MI → Supportive cardiac care

epidemiology: Inherited channelopathy causing prolonged QT interval and risk of sudden cardiac death; affects 1 in 2000 people.

emergency_markers: Prolonged QT with syncope or torsades

treatment_protocol: QTc >480ms with symptoms → Beta-blocker → Consider ICD

epidemiology: Least common cardiomyopathy; often secondary to amyloidosis, sarcoidosis, hemochromatosis, or radiation.
treatment_protocol: Identify etiology → Symptomatic treatment → Targeted therapy

epidemiology: Often seen in patients with prior MI or cardiomyopathy; life-threatening arrhythmia with high risk of SCD.
treatment_protocol: Stabilize → Identify cause → ICD/ablation

epidemiology: Dilated cardiomyopathy developing during late pregnancy or postpartum; more common in multiparous women and in Africa.
treatment_protocol: Confirm by echo → Standard HF treatment → Avoid ACE-I if pregnant

epidemiology: Affects ~1% globally; primary or secondary to heart, lung, or thromboembolic disease.
treatment_protocol: Confirm PH → Functional class → Targeted therapy

epidemiology: Common in elderly; due to fibrosis or ischemia of the sinus node; prevalence increases with age.
treatment_protocol: Symptomatic bradycardia → Pacemaker

epidemiology: Autosomal dominant; 1 in 500 prevalence; leading cause of sudden cardiac death in young athletes.
treatment_protocol: Risk stratification → Beta-blockers → ICD if high risk

epidemiology: Affects young women; autonomic dysfunction; increasing recognition post-viral syndromes (e.g., COVID).
treatment_protocol: Diagnose with tilt test → Lifestyle + meds

epidemiology: Common arrhythmia in older adults or those with structural heart disease; less frequent than AFib but similar risks.
treatment_protocol: Anticoagulation → Rate/rhythm control → Ablation

epidemiology: Often functional due to RV dilatation or pulmonary hypertension; common in elderly or those with left-sided heart failure.
treatment_protocol: Identify cause → Treat underlying → Surgical repair if severe

epidemiology: Incidence: ~3/100,000/year; more common in hypertensive men >60 years; classified as Stanford A or B.

timeline.symptom: Sudden severe chest pain radiating to the back

definitive: Medical for Type B unless complicated

treatment_protocol: Stanford A → Emergency surgery; Type B → BP control

epidemiology: Right-sided heart failure secondary to chronic lung disease; common in COPD, interstitial lung disease.
treatment_protocol: Confirm RV strain → Supportive + treat lung disease

epidemiology: Affects ~8/1000 live births; ASD and VSD most common; can be isolated or syndromic.
treatment_protocol: Echocardiogram → Optimize medically → Refer for repair

epidemiology: Life-threatening condition; usually secondary to trauma, malignancy, or pericarditis.
treatment_protocol: Confirm with echo → Urgent drainage

epidemiology: Genetic disorder affecting sodium channels, more common in Southeast Asian men; a major cause of sudden cardiac death in young adults.
treatment_protocol: Identify ECG pattern → Risk stratify → ICD if high risk

epidemiology: Rare genetic cardiomyopathy with prominent trabeculations; may present in childhood or adulthood.
treatment_protocol: Confirm diagnosis by imaging → HF meds → ICD if indicated

epidemiology: Common in young adults; includes AVNRT and AVRT; often idiopathic or due to accessory pathways.
treatment_protocol: Terminate acute episode → Electrophysiology study → Ablation

epidemiology: Late complication of unrepaired left-to-right shunt (e.g., VSD); occurs in childhood or adolescence if untreated.
treatment_protocol: Confirm PH + shunt reversal → Vasodilators → Transplant if needed

epidemiology: Can occur post-infectious, post-surgical, post-radiation; endemic in TB-prevalent areas.
treatment_protocol: Diagnose via imaging/hemodynamics → Surgery if symptomatic

epidemiology: Most common congenital cardiac abnormality (~1-2% prevalence); often asymptomatic until complications develop.

emergency_markers: Severe AS with syncope or angina

additional: CT or MRI of aorta (for root dilation)

treatment_protocol: Screen family → Monitor valve function → Surgery if severe stenosis or regurgitation

epidemiology: Congenital in most cases; accounts for 5-10% of all congenital heart defects; may also be acquired.

emergency_markers: Severe obstruction with syncope or right HF

treatment_protocol: Classify severity → Balloon dilation if moderate/severe

epidemiology: Seen in ~1-2% of the population; may coexist with PFO; often incidental finding.
treatment_protocol: Identify on echo → Antiplatelets or closure based on stroke risk

epidemiology: One of the most common causes of hospital admissions for chest pain; part of the acute coronary syndrome spectrum.
treatment_protocol: MONA → Antithrombotics → Cath lab if high risk

epidemiology: Occurs in ~30-50% of inferior STEMIs (RCA territory); often underdiagnosed.
treatment_protocol: Suspect with inferior MI → V4R → Fluids → PCI
